intro: Jamesonia chiapensis, commonly known as the Chiapas Jamesonia, is a flowering plant native to the humid forests of Central America. It belongs to the family Ericaceae, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in shaded, moist environments and thrives in well-drained, acidic soils. Its floral structure consists of five petals and is pollinated primarily by insects. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
